title: CUBICSPLINE exports the same value for tangents & values

labels.name: exporter
labels.description: This involves or affects the export process

labels.name: ReTest with master
labels.description: Old ticket that must be retested with current master

body:
Looking at the [Red Fox](http://www.mediafire.com/file/hssb4kgs0uo06pi/Animals+Pack+by+Quaternius.rar) model from [Quaternius](http://quaternius.com/assets.html) asset packs.

I'm using the default settings for the exporter with blender-2.80-798d2cadc307-win64

When i export the animated model after fixing up the bind pose, as described in #360 the final animation scales a bit.

![fox_broken](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1061030/54311062-12d47a00-4591-11e9-8ae1-9c0af393b732.gif)

There are two "easy" ways to fix this issue. Export with "Always Sample Animations", or go trough the dope sheet and mark any tracks that are linear data (but use bezier curves) as "linear". The screenshot below uses the second approach

![fox_works_v2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1061030/54310675-28956f80-4590-11e9-9ea1-bdb02fb3643c.gif)

So, in either fix case, the thing that actually works is switching to linear interpolation.

if we look at the y channel of "Bone.001" it contains the following data:

| Frame | Time  | in         | value      | out        |
|-------|-------|------------|------------|------------|
| 0     | 0.000 | 1.14048088 | 1.14048088 | 1.14048088 |
| 1     | 0.333 | 1.14048088 | 1.14048088 | 1.14048088 |
| 2     | 1.066 | 1.14048088 | 1.14048088 | 1.14048088 |

The problem does appears to be that the same value is in everything. The track in question is arranged as a line, i'd expect the tangents to be 0? This is the track in blender:

![track_blend_01](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1061030/54311563-13b9db80-4592-11e9-8fb3-d2992706679a.PNG)

With tangents showing

![track_blend_02](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1061030/54311578-1c121680-4592-11e9-84d9-2ebaa45c289e.PNG)

And this is the curve as interpolated by the data in the above table:

![interp_wrong](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1061030/54311860-b1ada600-4592-11e9-8302-3ff3c4668f9f.PNG)

VS linear interpolation, producing the correct result:

![interp_correct](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1061030/54311972-f9343200-4592-11e9-8b2b-46d399bc1fc6.PNG)

I haven't tried this yet, but i suspect i can work around this by:

```
tangent = value - tangent
```

The in tangent of the first frame should be 0 according to [this page](https://github.com/KhronosGroup/glTF/tree/master/specification/2.0)

> Implementation Note: The first in-tangent a1 and last out-tangent bn should be zeros as they are not used in the spline calculations.

title: Importer's handling of spec/gloss

labels.name: importer
labels.description: This involves or affects the import process

body:
I tried importing the [SpecGlossVsMetalRough](https://github.com/KhronosGroup/glTF-Sample-Models/tree/master/2.0/SpecGlossVsMetalRough) sample model, but the results don't look correct in Blender.  The two bottles use different techniques, but are supposed to look visually identical:

![specglossvsmetalrough_visualissue](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1235080/52971094-2884c400-3384-11e9-9065-2f77c5732f3d.jpg)

## Problem Nodes

Looking at the node graph produced by the importer, I see a couple issues:

- The specular color is not treated with the correct colorspace, per spec.  It should *not* be marked "Non-color data" because there is color in the RGB channels.  It should be a normal "Color" image.
- The roughness values are all zeros.

This screenshot shows nodes & links as created by the importer, organized for presentation here and marked up a bit, but functionally unchanged:

![Imported nodes](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1235080/52971183-86b1a700-3384-11e9-97c4-ec4487d8c5f2.png)

I'll present several different options here, starting with one that I think would be the easiest path to improvement.

## Option 1

In the screenshot below, the following edits have been made to the node structure:

* Spec/Gloss image switched to "Color" mode.
* The Alpha channel of the spec/gloss image (which corresponds to Glossiness) is sent through an Invert node (`1.0 - x`), and is used as the Roughness value for both the "Glossy BSDF" and "Diffuse BSDF" nodes.
* The Glossy BSDF and Diffuse BSDF nodes are added together at full strength.  (So a "Mix" shader with a factor was replaced by an "Add" shader, with no factor).

![diffuseglossnodes_simple](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1235080/52971348-1a837300-3385-11e9-8aa7-15862ef061da.png)

This node setup works pretty well for models like this one, where bright diffuse and bright specular colors are not used on the same pixel.  Technically, this is not "energy conserving", as it's missing one key formula from the `KHR_materials_pbrSpecularGlossiness` spec.  I'll address that in Option 2.

## Option 2

Building on top of Option 1, this adds 5 additional nodes to the graph.  It makes things fairly complex, but it replicates a [formula from the spec](https://github.com/KhronosGroup/glTF/tree/master/extensions/2.0/Khronos/KHR_materials_pbrSpecularGlossiness#specular---glossiness) that conserves energy by not allowing the diffuse and specular channels to double-up the reflected amount of light.

The formula in question is:  *c<sub>diff</sub>* = `diffuse.rgb * (1 - max(specular.r, specular.g, specular.b))`

![diffuseglossnodes_energyconserving](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1235080/52971712-7995b780-3386-11e9-92c9-cf77262b2d47.png)

In the above node graph, the specular color is separated out into R, G, B components, the max of all 3 components is found, inverted, and multiplied by the diffuse color texture.  The rest of the node graph is the same as Option 1 above.

This node graph produces a result that appears to exactly match the reference.  But it's a very complex node tree, and the exporter has really zero hopes of ever exporting something like this correctly, so I would certainly understand if this path is not followed.  But this one is the most technically correct as far as I know.

## Option 3

Blender Eevee has added a new `Specular` node, specifically for the spec/gloss workflow, that can take the place of all of this.

However, there are serious caveats:

- It's only Blender 2.80 Beta, not 2.79x.
- It's only Eevee, not Cycles.
- It's Beta and subject to change before release.

But there are also some advantages:

- It has a hookup for a baked ambient occlusion map, which we've not seen before in Blender at all.
- Its readability is the highest of any of these options.
- The exporter could easily be upgraded to round-trip something like this.

![eeveespecularnode](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1235080/52972106-c0d07800-3387-11e9-872d-f12454a91f33.png)

title: Node rotation not exported if node scale is 0

labels.name: exporter
labels.description: This involves or affects the export process

body:
The node rotation is not exported if the node's scale is 0.

A case where this actually causes an issue is where there is a static rotation and an animated scale, and the export happens to be done during a frame where the scale is 0.

This happens since `blender_object.matrix_local` doesn't contain rotation information when the scale is 0, and `gltf2_blender_gather_nodes.__gather_trans_rot_scale` uses `matrix_local`.

I'm not sure what a good clean solution is. Just using `rotation_*` wouldn't work since the `matrix_parent_inverse` has to somehow be taken into account. Not sure it's solvable in general, since the transformation might not even be decomposable. One non-ideal solution might be to detect if a scale axis is 0, and if so temporarily change the scale to 1 and recompute the rotation.

A workaround is to only animate the scale down to 0.00001.

title: Import: primitives add too many vertices

labels.name: importer
labels.description: This involves or affects the import process

body:
If a primitive has N elements in its POSITION accessor, N vertices always get added to the mesh, even if the indices accessor is, say, [0, 1, 2], so there should actually only be three vertices. This can result in a huge explosion in vertex count.

JoeyVrowl originally noticed this issue and made a test file. See https://github.com/KhronosGroup/UnityGLTF/issues/197, https://github.com/ksons/gltf-blender-importer/issues/29.

![extra-verts](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/11024420/52544916-7ba1ba00-2d79-11e9-81b7-25f79e02a3d2.png)  
_Taking apart a corner reveals many extra verts._

title: Inconsistent errors on GLTF export from Blender after modifying action

labels.name: exporter
labels.description: This involves or affects the export process

labels.name: ReTest with master
labels.description: Old ticket that must be retested with current master

body:
I have a model with 7 animations that exports ok, with or without actions being pushed down into NLA tracks, or saved as data blocks. I introduce a new animation following a workflow identical to the other seven (all rigged and exported in Mixamo, then imported to Blender 2.79b as FBX). The exporter will then typically start throwing errors, even though no settings have changed. A voodoo process ensues, trying things like purging data, removing then relinking actions, appending from a .blend file instead of importing the FBX directly, reinstalling the exporter, clearing keyframes, quitting and restarting, saving as a new file name, etc.

Sometimes one of these things works - or something else happens that makes it appear as though one of these things works. There's no rhyme or reason that I can discern. Establishing a reliable workflow for modifying an animation or introducing a new action has become fraught with fear.

This issue is seemingly related to [39](https://github.com/KhronosGroup/glTF-Blender-Exporter/issues/39) and [166](https://github.com/KhronosGroup/glTF-Blender-Exporter/pull/166). So far no workaround I've tried is very predictable.

Occasionally bones import from Mixamo with a -1 orientation on a given quaternion, which I'll correct in Blender. I've also noticed a high degree of weirdness when re-exporting things that play back fine in Blender, then break apart (unexpected rotations) when loaded in a three.js context. Applying all the loc/rot/scale makes no difference. Again, there's not a pattern for why this happens that I can figure out. Unsure if it's somehow related.

The steps that seem to semi-reliably get things exporting properly again include: purging data > clearing all animation data in the scene view, relinking actions by running through each of them in the action editor, saving as a new .blend file, quitting blender, reopening the file, and exporting. When that fails, as a last resort I will clear keyframes (but this often requires a fair amount of cleanup, or redoing an animation from scratch - ugh). Even this last step only works sporadically.

If I had any hair left to pull out I would. [This file is an example](http://nideffer.net/book/media/mod/game/pnpc/alvin/Alvin.blend) of one that was broken a bit ago, but started working again after taking the step of clearing keyframes on the root bone of the newly added action.

I'm currently using the most recent build of the gltf 2.0 Import-Export package.

Any feedback/tips much appreciated, and thanks for all the great work.

Hash: 690478027bd7

title: Import: Multiple animations with the same name overwrite one another

labels.name: importer
labels.description: This involves or affects the import process

body:
If the glTF has multiple animations that have the same name, there will only be one action after importing.

[Test file](https://github.com/KhronosGroup/glTF-Blender-IO/files/2798339/multiple-animations-one-name.zip)

This is affected by #253. Before #253, subsequent animations with the same name would just overwrite values in the previous ones. After #253, subsequent animations with the same name raise an exception (about the FCurve already existing).

body:
Importing a gltf file exported from Blender 2.79 or 2.8, normals do not conform to the one of the created object.

![normalesgltf](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/46683101/51124873-a999ea00-181f-11e9-912f-11c3bf5fc043.jpg)

title: BaseColorFactor imported at half strength

labels.name: importer
labels.description: This involves or affects the import process

body:
This is a relatively minor issue I noticed while investigating #185, and uses the same Sketchfab model as that issue:  https://sketchfab.com/models/885d9f60b3a9429bb4077cfac5653cf9

This car model has a translucent "ground shadow" object below it.  I import it into Blender 2.80, set the rendering engine to Cycles (because Eevee doesn't yet do translucency in a way that's compatible with our node graphs), and load a background environment.  This is what I see:

![basecolorfactorhalfannotated](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1235080/50297328-95461580-044a-11e9-9a45-15940e0ac1eb.png)

The source glTF model is a bit odd in that it contains a white shadow, not a black shadow.  But the glTF fixes that using a black `baseColorFactor`:

```
      "alphaMode": "BLEND",
      "doubleSided": true,
      "name": "Ground_SG",
      "pbrMetallicRoughness": {
        "baseColorFactor": [
          0,
          0,
          0,
          1
        ],
        "baseColorTexture": {
          "index": 3,
          "texCoord": 0
        },
```

In the Blender nodes above, you can see that this `baseColorFactor` has been added as `Color2`  to a multiply node created by the importer.  But Blender has its own "Fac" on this node, controlling the strength of the multiplication, and it's set to half, `0.5` by default.  This is a Blender default that didn't come from the glTF file.

So the `baseColorFactor` from the glTF is being imported at half strength, not full strength, and the shadow ends up medium-gray when it should be black.

This seems easily fixed by manually setting the "Fac" on the multiply node to `1.0`.  I believe this will cause the baseColorFactor to apply at full strength, as it should.

![basecolorfactorfull](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1235080/50297146-0f29cf00-044a-11e9-8693-244e5ba6d639.png)

title: Emissive factor missing?

labels.name: exporter
labels.description: This involves or affects the export process

body:
I downloaded this car model:  https://sketchfab.com/models/885d9f60b3a9429bb4077cfac5653cf9

After import/export trip through Blender, the emissive channel is not active.  Turns out that the exporter wrote an `emissiveTexture` but not an `emissiveFactor`.  The default `emissiveFactor` is `[0, 0, 0]` so as not to blast all models to full white.  But without the `emissiveFactor` being set, the `emissiveTexture` is multiplied by zero and has no effect.

(Also looks like blending may have been lost from the car windows, that's separate...)

Proper node name is `ShaderNodeOutputLight`.
They were renamed at this commit:
https://developer.blender.org/rB74fd17e9d788394fa5bf781bb3e60bca7617b22c

title: Classic Stretched Bone issue when exporting animation.

labels.name: exporter
labels.description: This involves or affects the export process

body: I am trying to pose and make a simple animation using "Spiderman Amazing Rig" below that hopefully works as GLTF anim: [Spiderman Amazing Rigged 2 2 CYCLE 009.blend.zip](https://github.com/KhronosGroup/glTF-Blender-IO/files/2660557/Spiderman.Amazing.Rigged.2.2.CYCLE.009.blend.zip) I am using Blender 2.79 and 2.8. So far 2.8 GLTF is giving a weird stretched bone animation and totally out of whack. I have seen similar issues posted in the past. There is no proper solution. [Screen Recording 2018-12-09 at 11.44.53 pm.mov.zip](https://github.com/KhronosGroup/glTF-Blender-IO/files/2660568/Screen.Recording.2018-12-09.at.11.44.53.pm.mov.zip) However, **KUPOMAN GLTF** export is the only add-on known out there that can export the animation above properly: https://github.com/Kupoman/blendergltf I tested it many times. It's not the problem if IK or FK, but sometimes if weight is abnormal it can cause error. Also the way Blender Rig sometimes is made without proper ROOT or non-connected bones... I don't know ¯\_(ツ)_/¯ I did convert the IK to FK using this add-on: https://github.com/chinedufn/blender-iks-to-fks It might be the way the rig was done causing the export to give weird stretching bones etc, but Kupoman GLTF export manage to export it even without me baking the IK.

title: Blender 2.8 GLTF exports both URI and Bufferview for Images

labels.name: exporter
labels.description: This involves or affects the export process

body:
The specification states only Bufferview or URI should be supplied in the gltf file, but both are present.
https://github.com/KhronosGroup/glTF/blob/master/specification/2.0/schema/image.schema.json
This is a GLTF+Textures+Bin export I'm using in Blender 2.8 Beta (Dec 3), the bin file is big too so I wonder if the textures are being packed anyways. The gltf loader library I'm using won't work in this case, it causes a validation failure.

```json
"images" : [
        {
            "bufferView" : 5,
            "mimeType" : "image/png",
            "name" : "rock-mat_normal.bmp",
            "uri" : "rock-mat_normal.png"
        },
        {
            "bufferView" : 6,
            "mimeType" : "image/png",
            "name" : "rock-mat_diffuseOriginal.bmp",
            "uri" : "rock-mat_diffuseOriginal.png"
        },
        {
            "bufferView" : 7,
            "mimeType" : "image/png",
            "name" : "rock-mat_orm.png",
            "uri" : "rock-mat_ormrock-mat_orm.png"
        }
    ],
```

title: All export formats are embedding texture buffers

labels.name: exporter
labels.description: This involves or affects the export process

body:
It appears that all export format options, including `JSON (.gltf + .bin + textures)`, are embedding texture buffers in the `.gltf` or `.bin` file, even when the textures are exported separately and called externally.

I'd mostly expect the buffers to be embedded for `.glb`, but there doesn't appear to be a way to _not_ embed them in `.gltf` or `.bin`.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4733018/49409145-464f6f00-f72d-11e8-9a3d-24cb05f1073a.png)

My guess is that the now removed `Embed buffers` option might now be automatically defaulting to true regardless of whether or not the buffers are used, but you folks would know better than I.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4733018/49409315-1d7ba980-f72e-11e8-87ba-b297bb61e94e.png)

body:
I did a quick run through of the beta to try and verify everything is working properly.  But a few things seems to be broken getting a GLTF scene exported and imported properly into various viewers.  I figured some test data might help so:   I've zipped an archive of the blender scene, textures and the gltf and glb exports files if it's usefull for testing.

the .scene contains an animated skinned mesh, a point, spot and directional light and a camera.

[runthrough_test.zip](https://github.com/KhronosGroup/glTF-Blender-IO/files/2631337/runthrough_test.zip)


if everything exported correctly the it should look like the image on the left.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/36362743/49259764-9954b980-f3ef-11e8-98ce-3f16a0f6e88c.png)

unfortunately, not 1-to-1 yet, but very close.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/36362743/49259952-3adc0b00-f3f0-11e8-93c5-5c7f7e85936b.png)

Issues.
-the camera does not come across 
-the direction light (red) doesn't seem to have the correct rotation.
-looks like the apply modifier export option didn't apply the subdivision on the sphere, 
-the HDR environment map did not export.

Some of these could be a viewer issues:  so I started a thread here as well:  https://github.com/donmccurdy/three-gltf-viewer/issues/120#issuecomment-442989532

title: alphaMode not set on transparent materials

labels.name: exporter
labels.description: This involves or affects the export process

body: When setting the alpha value of a material's baseColor to <1, I think we should default to `alphaMode=BLEND`. Currently the opacity value is written, but alphaMode is left blank, and defaults to OPAQUE. I can't see any equivalent to MASK on the Principled BSDF node, so I guess we can ignore that for now.

title: Traceback errors on export from Blender 2.8

labels.name: exporter
labels.description: This involves or affects the export process

body:
First, I'd like to say that you folks are doing killer work, and I enthusiastically look forward to being able to use this regularly with the `Principled BSDF` shader in the upcoming Blender release.

That said, I'm not sure how well the exporter should be working currently, as I understand it's still in development, as is Blender `2.8`, which makes it difficult for me to pinpoint the source of the errors.

I can't seem to export a simple cube to `gltf` or `glb` using the latest versions of both the exporter and Blender `2.8` with the settings below:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4733018/48974286-3bf0ef00-f022-11e8-962f-00ba210ac575.png)

I use practically the same workflow and settings with Blender `2.79b` and the `glTF-Blender-Exporter`, except I use the included `glTF Metallic Roughness` PBR nodes. In this case, I'm trying to use Blender's `Principled BSDF` shader and I'm getting the following errors:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4733018/48974385-feda2c00-f024-11e8-849f-8db2ece8daed.png)

This seems to be happening specifically when I check `Export selected only`, which I use often in my workflow.

---

I'm getting similar errors when trying the other options:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4733018/48974405-1e258900-f026-11e8-8db6-1a639c9efa89.png)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4733018/48974407-3a292a80-f026-11e8-8b91-e8aa15af91aa.png)

---

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4733018/48974438-904a9d80-f027-11e8-91a0-0b4ba9d8aef9.png)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4733018/48974436-7f019100-f027-11e8-9728-7a798eeebb8f.png)

---

The only combination that appears to work is this:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4733018/48974448-f800e880-f027-11e8-8a96-9a02dc662f6a.png)

However, it only seems to work the first time. After trying to re-export with those same settings, the resulting file is corrupt. It also exports all layers and doesn't let you select objects, which isn't typically ideal.

---

Here is a zip with the `.blend` file and a sample of the corrupt file:
[exporter_test.zip](https://github.com/KhronosGroup/glTF-Blender-IO/files/2612738/exporter_test.zip)

---

Blender version:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4733018/48974279-0d731400-f022-11e8-8327-68d25bccd1a7.png)

Exporter version:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4733018/48974331-347e1580-f023-11e8-81b1-398182a490be.png)

OS: Windows 10 x64

title: Issues with "Bake skinning constraints" option

labels.name: exporter
labels.description: This involves or affects the export process

body:
Hi,

I have some issues I wanted to share.

1. If I export [this file](https://github.com/KhronosGroup/glTF-Blender-Exporter/files/2545811/game_man_sketchbookb1.zip) with [these settings](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24359130/47964155-c6eb5480-e035-11e8-938a-5ccb13575c04.png), the exporter overwrites the source animations with the baked ones **in the actual blend file**. That's terrible. It's as if your compiler overwrote your source code with the compiled code. :smiley: 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24359130/47964191-37927100-e036-11e8-8b83-1e5f69053c0b.png)

It seems to be dependent on what bones are selected when exporting. I find that quite confusing.

2. Baking IK animations doesn't seem to work perfectly. Exporting the mentioned file with the mentioned settings, somethings wrong with the **left arm**, and occasionally the legs move in a strange, twitchy way.

FBX (correct)
![](https://thumbs.gfycat.com/MeaslyDesertedCrossbill-size_restricted.gif)

GLB (left arm moves wrong)
![](https://thumbs.gfycat.com/QualifiedThunderousGecko-size_restricted.gif)

Here's the [output files](https://github.com/KhronosGroup/glTF-Blender-Exporter/files/2545821/output.zip) if they were any help...

It's subtle, but it really isn't acceptable to have an exporter alter my animations.
There's an IK target for the left elbow that seems to get messed up. I know I could bake the animations by hand, but it would be a waste of time, since the FBX exporter bakes everything perfectly.

Anything I'm doing wrong? Thanks.

title: Exporter: Avoid to export invalid JSON format

labels.name: exporter
labels.description: This involves or affects the export process

body:
AFAIK the * .gltf file should be in JSON format:
https://github.com/KhronosGroup/glTF/tree/master/specification/2.0
»The format combines an easily parseable JSON scene description with one or more binary files representing geometry, animations, and other rich data. Binary data is stored in such a way that it can be loaded directly into GPU buffers without additional parsing or other manipulation.«

The JSON specification doesn't allow `NaN` as a value or number: https://json.org/

Exporting values as NaN breaks reading the glft file with the standard JSON parsers.
I couldn't trigger such a case with the blender-exporter[2] myself, but others claim that it happens
https://github.com/godotengine/godot/issues/21668
and try to push workarounds for the JSON parsers in the importer software.

In the attachment, only the first test-cube is validated by the JSON parser as correct.
In the blender-importer [1], the second one stops with python `TypeError: list indexes must be integers or slices, not float`, the third one loads without an error, which is in my opinion a mistake.

[test-NaN.zip](https://github.com/KhronosGroup/glTF-Blender-IO/files/2344880/test-NaN.zip)

I have created an issue only here, but it affects both
[1] https://github.com/julienduroure/gltf2-blender-importer
[2] https://github.com/KhronosGroup/glTF-Blender-Exporter

thanks!
